speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Go to him, Dolabella, bid him yield;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Being so frustrate, tell him he mocks

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The pauses that he makes.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Caesar, I shall.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Exit

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Enter DERCETAS, with the sword of MARK ANTONY

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Wherefore is that? and what art thou that darest

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Appear thus to us?

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: I am call'd Dercetas;

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Mark Antony I served, who best was worthy

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Best to be served: whilst he stood up and spoke,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: He was my master; and I wore my life

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: To spend upon his haters. If thou please

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: To take me to thee, as I was to him

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: I'll be to Caesar; if thou pleasest not,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: I yield thee up my life.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: What is't thou say'st?

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: I say, O Caesar, Antony is dead.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The breaking of so great a thing should make

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: A greater crack: the round world

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Should have shook lions into civil streets,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And citizens to their dens: the death of Antony

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Is not a single doom; in the name lay

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: A moiety of the world.

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: He is dead, Caesar:

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Not by a public minister of justice,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Nor by a hired knife; but that self hand,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Which writ his honour in the acts it did,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Hath, with the courage which the heart did lend it,

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: Splitted the heart. This is his sword;

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: I robb'd his wound of it; behold it stain'd

speaker: DERCETAS
text_entry: With his most noble blood.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Look you sad, friends?

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The gods rebuke me, but it is tidings

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To wash the eyes of kings.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: And strange it is,

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: That nature must compel us to lament

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Our most persisted deeds.

speaker: MECAENAS
text_entry: His taints and honours

speaker: MECAENAS
text_entry: Waged equal with him.

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: A rarer spirit never

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Did steer humanity: but you, gods, will give us

speaker: AGRIPPA
text_entry: Some faults to make us men. Caesar is touch'd.

speaker: MECAENAS
text_entry: When such a spacious mirror's set before him,

speaker: MECAENAS
text_entry: He needs must see himself.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: O Antony!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I have follow'd thee to this; but we do lance

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Diseases in our bodies: I must perforce

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Have shown to thee such a declining day,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Or look on thine; we could not stall together

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In the whole world: but yet let me lament,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: With tears as sovereign as the blood of hearts,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: That thou, my brother, my competitor

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In top of all design, my mate in empire,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Friend and companion in the front of war,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The arm of mine own body, and the heart

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Where mine his thoughts did kindle,--that our stars,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Unreconciliable, should divide

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Our equalness to this. Hear me, good friends--

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: But I will tell you at some meeter season:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter an Egyptian

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The business of this man looks out of him;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: We'll hear him what he says. Whence are you?

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: A poor Egyptian yet. The queen my mistress,

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: Confined in all she has, her monument,

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: Of thy intents desires instruction,

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: That she preparedly may frame herself

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: To the way she's forced to.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Bid her have good heart:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She soon shall know of us, by some of ours,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: How honourable and how kindly we

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Determine for her; for Caesar cannot live

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To be ungentle.

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: So the gods preserve thee!

speaker: Egyptian
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Come hither, Proculeius. Go and say,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: We purpose her no shame: give her what comforts

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The quality of her passion shall require,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Lest, in her greatness, by some mortal stroke

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She do defeat us; for her life in Rome

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Would be eternal in our triumph: go,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And with your speediest bring us what she says,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And how you find of her.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Caesar, I shall.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Gallus, go you along.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exit GALLUS

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Where's Dolabella,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To second Proculeius?

speaker: All
text_entry: Dolabella!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Let him alone, for I remember now

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: How he's employ'd: he shall in time be ready.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Go with me to my tent; where you shall see

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: How hardly I was drawn into this war;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: How calm and gentle I proceeded still

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In all my writings: go with me, and see

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: What I can show in this.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exeunt
